properties.name: Preventing Fire Tree’s Extinction on Guam National Wildlife Refuge
properties.description: The critically endangered Serianthes nelsonii, or fire tree, is native to Guam and the nearby island of Rota. Currently, only one adult tree of the species grows at Guam National Wildlife Refuge, which has been impacted by termites; fewer than 50 mature trees remain on Rota. 15 outplanted seedlings currently survive on Guam Refuge. Threats to this species include high winds associated with typhoons, and an almost complete lack of regeneration because of predation by Philippine deer, feral hogs, and insects. This project seeks to increase the capacity of of the Guam Refuge nursery to propagate and outplant seeds from the tree in areas free of deer and other hooved animals. The team will also install fencing to deter animals from feeding on seedlings. The goal is to increase the number of fire trees from 15 to 45 individuals at four secured areas on the Refuge. Improvements to the Refuge nursery may also benefit other rare plant recovery projects on the Refuge. Fencing will likely benefit the host plants for Hypolimnas octocula, a Candidate butterfly species, and recovery of understory necessary for Candidate tree snail species.
properties.caption: Fire tree Credit: Tigran Tadevosyan, CC-BY 4.0

properties.name: Recovering Golden Paintbrush
properties.description:
Over 90% of the prairie ecosystem located with the Puget Trough/Willamette Valley/Georgia Basin ecoregion has been lost or modified since the mid 1800s. Direct loss of prairie to agriculture and development has been the greatest long-term factor accounting for the rarity of golden paintbrush and other native prairie species. These same prairies have been extensively degraded by invasive non-native plants as well as annual and perennial weeds.

The project aims to improve the status of golden paintbrush with the goal of seeing it removed from the endangered species list. Team members plan to ensure at least 15 protected populations with more than 1,000 flowering plants each. On project sites including William L. Finley and Basket Slough National Wildlife Refuges in the Willamette Valley, the team plans to use prescribed burning, mowing, herbicide treatments and tree and shrub removal to reduce invasive species and restore native prairie. Before the Service can propose delisting the plant, 20 stable populations of at least 1,000 flowering plants each must be distributed through its historic range. Other plants likely to benefit from this project include Taylor’s checkerspot butterfly, streaked horned lark, mazama pocket gopher, Fender’s blue butterfly, Kincaid’s lupine and Willamette daisy.
properties.caption: Golden paintbrush Credit: Judy Lantor, USFWS
refuges: William L. Finley National Wildlife Refuge

properties.name: Recovering Columbian White-tailed Deer
properties.description:
Historically Columbian white-tailed deer were common in riparian areas along major rivers west of the Cascade Mountains in Oregon and Washington. The decline in Columbian white-tailed deer numbers was rapid with the arrival and settlement of pioneers in the fertile river valleys. Conversion of brushy riparian land to agriculture, urbanization, uncontrolled sport and commercial hunting cause the extirpation of this deer over most of it’s range by the early 1900’s.

The project team aims to improve the status of the Columbian white-tailed deer by ensuring two viable populations of the species — one, at Julia Butler Hansen National Wildlife Refuge, and the other at Ridgefield National Wildlife Refuge. The project will involve supplementing the deer population at Ridgefield Refuge, where some animals were previously moved to reduce their vulnerability to a threatened dike failure. The project will also establish 50 acres of grass/forb meadow and 50 acres of permanent wooded plots and corridors of mixed deciduous trees and shrubs as deer habitat.

On October 6, 2015 the Columbian white-tailed deer was proposed for downlisting from endangered to threatened due to recovery efforts.
properties.caption: Columbian white-tailed deer Credit: Blu Chaney, USFWS
refuges: Julia Butler Hansen National Wildlife Refuge

properties.name: Conserving Endangered Fish and Other Sensitive Species
properties.description:
The northern headwaters of the Rio Yaqui watershed begin in the Chiricachua, Pedregosa, Peloncillo, and Animas Mountains. The river originates on San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge and flows 300 miles south to it’s mouth in the Gulf of California. The species of fish in the Rio Yaqui are endemic and unique, being totally dependent upon protected, high quality springs, seeps, and associated healthy and dependable wetlands. The short stretches of perennial flow on the San Bernardino and Leslie Canyon National Wildlife Refuges are two of three remaining natural habitats for these fish in the United States; these refuges were established specifically to protect habitat for these fish.

The project team will work with conservation-minded landowners to speed the recovery of five rare fish (Yaqui chub, Yaqui topminnow, Huachuca water umbel, beautiful shiner and Yaqui catfish), one rare amphibian (Chiricahua leopard frog) and one rare invertebrate (San Bernardino springtail). Restoration efforts will focus on wetland and upland habitat in southeastern Arizona and southwestern New Mexico. Among actions planned are repairing eroded habitat, removing invasive plant species, and constructing and restoring wetlands. The actions are also expected to benefit many non-listed species.
properties.caption: Photo: Chiricahua leopard frog. Credit: Jim Rorabaugh, USFWS

properties.name: Preventing the Extinction of the Oregon Silverspot Butterfly, Oregon and Washington
properties.description: Only five populations of Oregon silverspot butterfly remain in the wild and each is at a great risk of extirpation. The primary limiting factor is lack of suitable habitat. The butterfly requires coastal prairie habitat with large numbers of early blue violets to feed the caterpillars and an abundance of nectar plants to support breeding adult butterflies. The project team will restore suitable habitat and introduce a population of the Oregon silverspot butterfly to the Nestucca Bay and Willapa National Wildlife Refuges. The butterfly requires coastal prairie habitat with large numbers of early blue violets to feed the caterpillars and an abundance of nectar plants to support breeding adult butterflies. The team will control invasive plants and remove encroaching trees and shrubs. The team will also collect seeds and propagate plants to be planted in restored habitat. There are only five remaining populations of Oregon silverspot butterfly in existence; four in Oregon and one in northern California. Currently there are no populations of this species at either Refuge. Species that can additionally benefit are the sweat bee and obscure bumble bee.
properties.caption: Oregon silverspot butterfly Credit: USDA

properties.name: Restoration on the Middle Rio Grande to Benefit Rio Grande Silvery Minnow, Southwestern Willow Flycatcher and Western Yellow-billed Cuckoo
properties.description:
The goal of the project is to create new nursery habitat for the Rio Grande silvery minnow by restoring the river-floodplain connection to promote seasonal flooding. This habitat will be restored and enhanced as nesting and foraging riparian habitat for the endangered southwestern willow flycatcher and western yellow-billed cuckoo along the Middle Rio Grande corridor on Sevilleta National Wildlife Refuge.

To increase habitat for the southwestern willow flycatcher and western yellow-billed cuckoo, the project team will remove invasive plants and plant Gooding’s willow, coyote willow and cottonwood poles in new and existing restoration areas, while ensuring water reaches forested areas in May and June by creating channels to connect the river to the riparian units. Similar projects have been completed to the north and south of this project site. Completing this project will create greatly needed “stepping stones” of habitat. Species that can additionally benefit are the New Mexico meadow jumping mouse and pecos sunflower.
properties.caption: Southwestern willow flycatcher Credit: Jim Rorabaugh, USFWS

properties.name: Applying Strategic Habitat Conservation to the Restoration of the South Texas Coastal Corridor for the Recovery of Ocelot and Northern Aplomado Falcon
properties.description: A recent population viability analysis suggests that the ocelot is likely to go extinct in Texas in under 45 years without significant intervention. Ocelots prefer dense thornscrub communities; approximately 93% of Tamaulpan thornscrub has been altered for development in the Lower Rio Grande Valley and less than 1% remains in all of south Texas. This project will increase the amount of suitable Tamaulipan thornscrub and coastal prairie habitat in the South Texas Coastal Corridor that is available to endangered ocelots and northern aplomado falcons. The Tamaulipan thornscrub and coastal prairie are tightly interspersed across the landscape on or near both the Laguna Atascosa and Lower Rio Grande Valley National Wildlife Refuges in south Texas. The Texas Department of Transportation will install strategic wildlife crossing over the next three years within the Coastal Corridor to reduce vehicle strikes, which are the most common mortality factor for ocelots. The goals of the project are to connect isolated parcels of existing, optimal habitat and restore thornscrub and coastal prairie habitat to increase landscape level habitat. Species that can additionally benefit are the Sprague’s pipit and long-billed curlew.
properties.caption: Ocelot Credit: Richard, CC BY-NC-SA 2.0
refuges: Lower Rio Grande Valley National Wildlife Refuge

properties.name: Topeka Shiner Recovery in Southwest Minnesota
properties.description: This project will help stabilize the Minnesota population of the endangered Topeka shiner. Populations of the Topeka shiner have steadily declined due to habitat destruction, sedimentation and changes in water quality, including from stream-bank bank erosion. The goals of the project are to create and restore off-channel habitat, improve fish passage through barrier removal, stabilize stream banks, make instream channel modifications and restore surrounding wetlands and grasslands. The team plans to enter into easements on 130 acres of habitat near Windom Wetland Management District and there is a significant amount of interest from landowners in future participation. The project will focus on continuing stabilization projects in locations where other off-channel improvements can be made that complement each other to provide both improved water quality habitat as well as refuge habitat. Species that can additionally benefit are the Blanding’s turtle, Blanchard’s cricket frog, creek heelsplitter and plains topminnow.
properties.caption: Topeka shiner fishling Credit: USFWS

properties.name: Captive Rearing the Federally Endangered Hine’s Emerald Dragonfly
properties.description: The endangered Hine’s emerald dragonfly survives in only six populations in the Midwest, with the Illinois population in the most danger of disappearing in the near-term. The Illinois population is highly valuable genetically and the loss of this population would have strong implications for the persistence of the species as a whole. This population exists in a rapidly developing urban matrix that has fragmented the habitat into small patches. The project team at the Upper Mississippi River National Wildlife and Fish Refuge Complex and Genoa Fish Hatchery will construct enclosures for egg hatching and larval placement, collect Hine’s emerald dragonfly eggs from the wild, hatch and rear in captivity, and then augment the wild population. The goals of the project are to increase the viability and preserve high genetic diversity found in the Illinois population, produce captive-reared adults from field-collected eggs, and augment wild population. The project team has identified ideal breeding habitat and it is currently in the process of being restored. Species that can additionally benefit are the Lakeside daisy, Blanding’s turtle and spotted turtle.
properties.caption: Hine’s Emerald Dragonfly Credit: USFWS
refuges: Upper Mississippi River National Wildlife and Fish Refuge Complex

properties.name: Preventing Extinction and Improving Habitat for the Bartram’s Scrub-Hairstreak and Florida Leafwing
properties.description:
South Florida is currently seeing widespread loss of butterflies, with four species listed as endangered. Bartram’s scrub-hairstreak is a small, grey butterfly dependent on a single host plant called pineland croton. This particular species of croton is only found in the globally imperiled pine rockland forest communities and can be found on Big Pine Key including in National Key Deer Refuge and in Everglades National Park. Ninety percent of the pine rockland on mainland south Florida and much of the habitat in the Florida Keys has been cleared for development over the last 100 years and the natural fire regiment has been drastically interrupted. The Florida leafwing also shares overlapping habitat with the hairstreak and will benefit from this project.

The goals of the project are to enhance habitat to prevent local extinction and benefit potential reintroductions of target species and create new ‘stepping stone’ habitat patches. Species that can additionally benefit are the Key deer, marsh rabbit, garber’s spurge, wedge spurge, sand flax, Big Pine partridge pea and Keys ribbon snake.
properties.caption: Bartram's scrub-hairstreak Credit: Holly Salvato, USFWS

properties.name: Mountain Sweet Pitcher Plant Recovery Initiative
properties.description: Mountain bogs are widely accepted as among the rarest and most imperiled habitat types in the southeastern United States, and hotspots for biodiversity, endemism and rare and declining plant species, including the mountain sweet pitcher plant. There are only four natural populations of this plant left in North Carolina, down from 23, and five known sites in South Carolina. There is a need to increase the size of partially protected sites to be fully protected in order to bring the species closer to the recovery goal of having four protected and self-sustaining populations. The project team will work with a local land conservancy to identify parcels for permanent protection through easements, restore protected habitat to conditions beneficial for the mountain sweet pitcher plant and actively manage populations in order to become self-sustaining, including at Mountain Bogs National Wildlife Refuge. The team will implement regular prescribed burning and mechanical removal of invasive species. In addition, the team will remove material and restore a previously filled wetland and augment the mountain sweet pitcher plant populations from on-site soil. Species that can additionally benefit are the swamp pink, montane purple pitcher plant and bog rose orchid.
properties.caption: Mountain sweet pitcher-plant Credit: Gary Peeples, USFWS

properties.name: Seabeach Amaranth Restoration on Atlantic Coast National Wildlife Refuges
properties.description:
Seabeach amaranth is endemic to the Atlantic Coast from South Carolina to Massachusetts. This annual plant species is vulnerable to climate change, sea level rise, development of beachfront property and increased beach use. Range-wide the species has rapidly declined over the past 13 years from over 200,000 plants recorded each year to only 1,320 plants in 2013, a 99.5% reduction. There is an urgent need to collect seeds from as many populations as possible in order to preserve the genetic diversity from across the range of the species. In order to continue its recovery, it is necessary to establish more self-sustaining populations in natural areas that are less vulnerable to man-made threats and more resilient to climate change and sea level rise.

The project team from multiple national wildlife refuges (Monomoy, Nantucket, Edwin B. Forsythe, Cape May, Chincoteague and Cape Romain) will collect seeds, propagate plants, plant seed plots in protected areas and install protective fencing. The goals of the project are to reestablish the species throughout its natural range. Seeds that are not used immediately for restoration will be placed in long-term storage at the North Carolina Botanical Gardens and the National Center for Genetic Resource Preservation. Species that can additionally benefit are the piping plover, northeastern tiger beetle and loggerhead sea turtle.
properties.caption: Seabeach amaranth Credit: Dale Suiter, USFWS
refuges: Edwin B. Forsythe National Wildlife Refuge

properties.name: Puritan Tiger Beetle Habitat Enhancement and Population Stabilization in the Connecticut River Watershed
properties.description: The New England population of Puritan tiger beetle, one of two genetically distinct populations, is found solely on the shores of the Connecticut River within Silvio O. Conte National Fish and Wildlife Refuge and in close proximity to Stewart B. McKinney National Wildlife Refuge. Range-wide population declines have occurred due to dams on the Connecticut River and numerous flood control dams on river tributaries. Dams reduce frequency and magnitude of natural floods, alter low flow periods, and inundate previously suitable riverine habitat behind dams. As a result, available beach habitat has substantially declined. Urbanization and riverbank stabilization has also contributed to the decline. The project team will remove debris and control vegetative encroachment via mechanical removal and herbicide, collect adult tiger beetles for the captive rearing program, and translocate captive reared beetles into restored habitat. The goals of the project are to secure the existing Connecticut, establish two new populations in New England to meet recovery criteria, restore beach habitat and establish a captive rearing lab at Cronin Station. Species that can additionally benefit are the tidewater mucket, yellow lampmussel, cobra clubtail, midland clubtail, hairy necked tiger beetle and sandbar willow.
properties.caption: Puritan tiger beetle Credit: Susi von Oettingen, USFWS
refuges: Silvio O. Conte National Fish and Wildlife Refuge
Stewart B. McKinney National Wildlife Refuge

properties.name: Red-cockaded Woodpecker Reintroduction
properties.description:
The red-cockaded-woodpecker was a common species throughout the pinelands of the southeastern U.S., from New Jersey to Louisiana. Loss of habitat and changes in silvaculture practices have led to the decline of this species throughout its range. Presently, one population (10 breeding pairs) occurs within Virginia, which is located on The Nature Conservancy’s Piney Grove Preserve. It is the most northern population still surviving on the East Coast (the species has been extirpated from Maryland and New Jersey). Great Dismal Swamp National Wildlife Refuge and adjacent lands in Virginia and North Carolina are part of the Northern Essential Support Zone for this species. Currently there are approximately 16,000 acres of designated pine habitat available.

The project team will install artificial cavities in established cluster sites, capture red-cockaded woodpeckers from two sites, transport and release birds, and monitor nests and nest activities. The goal of the project is to establish a second viable breeding population in Virginia, including breeding clusters. The habitat work with pond pine pocosin and the reestablishment of the red-cockaded woodpecker will determine the viability of these habitats as climate change affects areas prone to sea level rise. Species that can additionally benefit are the northern long-eared bat, brown-headed nuthatch, chuck-will’s widow, rusty blackbird and black bear.
properties.caption: Red-cockaded woodpecker Credit: USFWS
refuges: Great Dismal Swamp National Wildlife Refuge

properties.name: Wetlands and Whooping Cranes: A Strategic Approach to Habitat Protection, Restoration and Enhancement in Nebraska’s Rainwater Basin
properties.description:
The whooping crane is a critically imperiled species with just 300 in the Wood Buffalo/Aransas population. The safety of whooping cranes migrating each year between their wintering grounds in Texas and their breeding grounds in Canada remains one of the biggest challenges to the species’ survival. The Rainwater Basin Wetland Management District in south-central Nebraska is a high-value migration stopover habitat for the crane, as well as many other migratory species. Work in the area to restore previously drained wetlands and re-fill unused irrigation pits is ongoing. However, when wetlands are bisected by ownership, restoration may not be an option. Recently, funds under the North American Wetlands Conservation Act were approved for the purchase of 120 acres of habitat that will place wetlands that were previously under partial private ownership completely under public ownership. Once the land is acquired, restoration of the habitat, which has been highly modified by pits, dikes, drains, sedimentation and fill activities, can move forward. The wetland protection and restoration, as well as watershed enhancement, will help provide reliable stopover habitat for the whooping cranes during both spring and fall migrations.

The long-term goals of this project are to enhance and restore high quality habitat in the Kansas-Nebraska Gap, enhance watershed functions by filling abandoned irrigation pits, protect wetlands by installing perimeter fence and increase water flow through culvert replacement. To achieve the goals, the project team will remove five irrigation pits in the watershed and two dugouts in the wetland, conduct plantings of high-diversity grasslands and forbs, including milkweed to benefit monarch butterflies and replace area culverts.
properties.caption: Credit: Operation Migration, CC BY 2.0
programs: Partners for Fish and Wildlife Service

properties.name: Lesser Prairie-Chicken Conservation and Recovery in Kansas
properties.description:
The primary threats to the recently listed lesser prairie-chicken include grassland invasion by woody plants, improper grazing systems, altered fire regimes and climate change. The Kansas lesser prairie-chicken population has been designated to support 70% of the Western Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies’ Conservation Plan five-state population goal. Within Kansas, habitat fragmentation, primarily from the eastern red cedar is the major threat to the lesser prairie-chicken. The recent explosion in eastern red cedar (23,000% increase) has caused reductions in lesser prairie-chicken habitat. Previous fire cycles once kept the eastern red cedar population in check, but those cycles have been altered. The goals of this project are to restore and/or enhance 15,000 acres of publicly and privately owned prairie habitat utilized by the lesser prairie-chicken for nesting and brood rearing on and near Quivira and Kirwin National Wildlife Refuges. The project team will remove eastern red cedars, plant native grasses and shrubs and implement prescribed burning and grazing system modifications to include fence installation/removal and livestock water facility enhancements.

Added goals of the team are to implement grassland restoration projects and expand upon occupied acres to enhance the distribution and connectivity of populations and increase population size. Establishing and maintaining partnerships with stakeholders will help increase awareness and adoption of conservation measures and practices among landowners and managers. Species that can additionally benefit are the Sprague’s pipit, Arkansas darter, ferruginous hawk, grasshopper sparrow, loggerhead shrike, Cassin’s sparrow, upland sandpiper, bobolink, northern harrier, greater prairie-chicken and short-eared owl.
properties.caption: Lesser prairie-chicken. Credit: USDA

properties.name: Arapaho and UL Bend National Wildlife Refuges Black-footed Ferret Cooperative Recovery Initiative
properties.description:
The black-footed ferret is among the rarest animals in North America. Great strides have been made in the recovery of the species, but full recovery will not be assured until self-sustaining populations are secured in the wild. Due to eradication efforts by private landowners of prairie dogs – the black-footed ferret’s primary prey – relatively few prairie dog complexes of sufficient size remain for the ferret. Additionally, sylvatic plague has severely impacted both prairie dog and black-footed ferret populations on an estimated 71% of reintroduction sites. UL Bend and Arapaho National Wildlife Refuges are important sites for black-footed ferret conservation efforts. The project team will focus on invasive species control, captive propagation and release of ferrets, and the annual trials of a plague vaccine.

The goals of the project are to develop two self-sustaining populations of at least 30 breeding adults at each refuge (contributing 20% toward the recovery goal of a minimum of 10 populations with 30 breeding adults), expand occupied black-tailed prairie dog habitat at UL Bend Refuge from 1,300 acres to 4,000 acres, expand occupied white-tailed prairie dog habitat at Arapaho Refuge and surrounding Bureaus of Land Management lands from 2,800 acres to 6,000 acres, and develop a strategy for the large-scale implementation of an orally delivered sylvatic plague vaccine that can be used throughout the range of the black-footed ferret.
properties.caption: Black-footed ferret kits Credit: Ryan Moehring, USFWS

properties.name: Thin-layer Sediment Augmentation on the Pacific Coast: An Essential Sea Level Rise Adaptation Technique Proposed at the Seal Beach National Wildlife Refuge to Ensure the Survival of the Endangered Light-Footed Ridgway’s Rail
properties.description:
The lack of suitable nesting habitat in the coastal marshes of southern California is a severe limiting factor to the growth of the light-footed Ridgway’s rail (formerly light-footed clapper rail) population. When cordgrass of a suitable height is not available, breeding rails may build nests in both low, sparse grass and higher, exposed areas, putting the nests at risk of destruction or predation. At Anaheim Bay, the low elevation of the marsh plain, a result of subsidence, results in cordgrass being totally submersed by only moderately high tides. As sea levels rise, the conditions at Anaheim Bay will be replicated in marshes throughout coastal southern California, putting the entire light-footed Ridgway’s rail population at risk.

Additionally, wetland migration inland is impossible for this highly urbanized area. The project team will apply a thin-layer of clean sediment over 10 acres of degraded cordgrass habitat and then conduct intensive monitoring of the area. If successful, this project could be a model for modifying land-locked urban habitats. The goals of the project are to ensure long-term survival of species by implementing sea-level rise adaptation strategy, conduct sediment augmentation of a pilot site to elevate marsh, improve cordgrass nesting habitat for the rail and increase the diversity and abundance of invertebrates on and near Seal Beach National Wildlife Refuge. Species that can additional benefit are the salt marsh bird’s-beak, Ridgway’s rail (formerly California clapper rail), salt marsh harvest mouse and Belding’s savannah sparrow.
properties.caption: Light-footed ridgeway's rail Credit:

properties.name: Increasing Populations of Western Snowy Plovers and Streaked Horned Larks on Willapa National Wildlife Refuge and Adjacent Coastal Beaches
properties.description: The project team will measurably improve the number of breeding pairs of threatened Western snowy plovers at the Leadbetter Point unit of Willapa National Wildlife Refuge in Washington State and enhance their reproductive success towards achieving recovery criteria. The project will also improve the number of horned lark breeding territories at Leadbetter Point to prevent local extirpation of the Washington Coast population. This will be accomplished through intensive habitat management of breeding and wintering habitats and reductions of disturbance stressors at the refuge and nearby Leadbetter Point State Park. Habitat restoration is anticipated to be on a scale where dynamic ecological processes can sustain the ecosystem in a natural state that requires limited future maintenance. These efforts can additionally benefit the state’s only known population of pink sand verbena plants, located at the refuge.
properties.caption: Federally Threatened Western snowy plover; USFWS

properties.name: Preventing the Extinction of the Endangered Plants of the ‘Ewa Plains through Restoration and Reintroduction at the Kalaeloa Unit of the Pearl Harbor National Wildlife Refuge
properties.description: The Kalaeloa Unit of the Pearl Harbor National Wildlife Refuge in Hawai‘i was established to protect and enhance the habitat for the endangered coastal dryland plants ‘Ewa round-leaved chaff-flower and ‘Ewa Plains ‘akoko. Due to intense industrial, military, and agricultural development of these coastal areas since the 19th century, only about 10% of the species habitat remains in Hawai‘i. The project team will help recover endemic species by establishing reproducing populations on the 37.4-acre Kalaeloa Unit of Pearl Harbor National Wildlife Refuge. A number of imperiled species can additionally benefit, such as anchialine pool shrimp, ​‘ōpae ‘ula, wiliwili, sandalwood, naio, maiapilo and Hawaiian cotton as well as endangered insect and plant species, including: yellow-faced bees, koʻokoʻolau, ʻāwiwi, kōkōmālei, 'Ohai, Oʻahu vigna, Hawaiʻi lady's nightcap, Kauaʻi spurge, smoothfruit chewstick, Oʻahu chewstick, Ma'o hau hele, wahine noho kula, nehe, angularfruit ma'oloa, kuluʻī, sprawling schiedea, waiʻanae range schiedea and Hawai'i scaleseed.
properties.caption: Round-leaved chaff flower by David Eickhof, CC BY 2.0

properties.name: Recovery of Chiricahua Leopard Frog and Northern Mexican Gartersnake through Landscape-Scale Eradication of Bullfrogs on and Around Buenos Aires National Wildlife Refuge
properties.description: The American bullfrog, which is non-native to southern Arizona, has caused significant declines of other frogs and garter snakes in the area. Over the past 15 years, Buenos Aires National Wildlife Refuge and a variety of cooperators have engaged in efforts to eliminate bullfrogs at landscape scales in and around the refuge. However, one area remains as the last stronghold for bullfrogs in the larger area. The project team will take a systemic approach to bullfrog eradication, including removal of bullfrogs with continuous measuring and monitoring of sites. These efforts will help eliminate impacts to threatened species, such as Chiricahua leopard frogs and northern Mexican gartersnakes and increase persistence of both species on the landscape-level scale. Native aquatic species that can additionally benefit include the lowland leopard frog.
properties.caption: Photo: Chiricahua leopard frog. Credit: Jim Rorabaugh, USFWS

properties.name: Karner Blue Butterfly Assisted Migration in Western Wisconsin
properties.description: The project team will strengthen and expand recovery efforts for endangered Karner blue butterfly populations in western Wisconsin and refine the assisted migration technique for reestablishing the butterfly to restored habitat by harvesting wild lupine (host plant) and nearby vegetation during the portion of the life cycle of the butterfly when eggs are present. The vegetation and eggs will be moved to alternate locations with sufficient wild lupine to sustain the larvae once hatched. With the climate changing and Karen blue populations decreasing, robust populations in western Wisconsin coupled with a cost-effective reintroduction methodology will ensure reintroduction attempts are possible when suitable habitat is identified. Work will occur within the St. Croix Wetlands Management District in Wisconsin, primarily on Waterfowl Production Areas. Other species that can benefit are the monarch butterfly and prairie bush clover.
properties.caption: Karner blue butterfly. Credit: USFWS

properties.name: Recovery of the Eastern Prairie Fringed Orchid through Establishment of a Highly Viable Population at Shiawassee National Wildlife Refuge
properties.description: The eastern prairie fringed orchid is currently experiencing population decline mainly due to the loss of habitat from the drainage and development of wetlands. Other reasons for the current decline include succession to woody vegetation, competition from non-native species and over-collection. The project team will establish a population of threatened eastern prairie fringed orchid at Shiawassee National Wildlife Refuge in Michigan using plant orchid plugs in suitable habitat at the refuge and restore and manage an orchid population on private land near the refuge to harvest seed from the private population to supplement the planted plugs. Monitoring of the plugs and hand pollination of orchids on the private land will occur for three years. In addition, populations will be assessed for the duration of this project to prioritize and focus future recovery actions.
properties.caption: Eastern prairie fringed orchid Credit: Joseph Haas, USFWS

properties.name: Frosted Flatwoods Salamander Management and Monitoring on the St. Marks National Wildlife Refuge, Florida
properties.description: Habitat loss, climate change and feral hogs are having an impact on ephemeral ponds and surrounding upland pine flatwoods in Florida. Recent surveys have indicated steep declines in threatened frosted flatwoods salamanders as a result. In addition, a lack of frequent growing season fires can cause a decline in suitable vegetation in the ponds and impact the adjoining pine flatwoods where the salamander spends most of its life. On St. Marks National Wildlife Refuge, the project team will reintroduce a more frequent and natural fire regime, use mechanical and herbicide habitat treatments, control feral hog depredation and place salamander larvae into covered artificial ponds to remove the main sources of mortality and help increase survival to metamorphosis. The juvenile salamanders will be returned to their pond of origin for the first two years, and afterwards to restored ponds with suitable upland habitat to facilitate repopulation. The restoration efforts will also benefit other species, such as the red-cockaded woodpecker, gopher tortoise and northern bobwhite.
properties.caption: Frosted flatwoods salamander in the advanced larval stage. Credit: USGS

properties.name: Restoration of the Endangered Dwarf Wedgemussel in the Connecticut River Watershed
properties.description: The center of the range of the endangered dwarf wedgemussel is found within the Silvio O. Conte National Fish and Wildlife Refuge, in rivers and streams of the Connecticut River watershed. Recently, a substantial reduction in the distribution and abundance of this freshwater mussel was documented in the mainstem Connecticut and Ashuelot Rivers, once thought to host the largest occurrences for the species. To reach the recovery goal of maintaining a viable population of the species throughout its range, the project team proposes to propagate the mussel at the Richard Cronin Aquatic Resource Center and reintroduce the species to previously occupied suitable habitat.
properties.caption: Dwarf wedgemussel. Credit: Susi von Oettingen, USFWS
refuges: Silvio O. Conte National Fish and Wildlife Refuge

properties.name: Restoring Endangered Freshwater Mussels on a Landscape Scale
properties.description: The long-term goal of this multi-region, multi-species recovery project is to recover endangered mussels on a landscape-level scale. The project team will build on success and lessons learned from a previous Cooperative Recovery Initiative funded project and apply the best tools and techniques to establish new populations of mussels sufficient to establish and retain genetic connectivity under future climate pressures. The target species include: clubshell, orange-foot pimpleback, purple cat's paw pearlymussel, spectaclecase, fanshell, rink pink, white wartyback and sheepnose.
properties.caption: Sheepnose. Credit: USFWS
refuges: Ohio River Islands National Wildlife Refuge

properties.name: Increasing Benefits of Piping Plover Nest Exclosures on Atlantic Coast National Wildlife Refuges
properties.description: The goals of this project are to increase the abundance and population growth of Atlantic Coast piping plovers on eighteen national wildlife refuges (Chincoteague, Eastern Shore of Virginia, Edwin B. Forsythe, the five refuges that make up the Rhode Island Complex, Monomoy, Parker River, Rachel Carson and the seven refuges that make up the Long Island Complex). Predation is a major pervasive threat impinging on productivity and survival of breeding Atlantic Coast piping plovers. Also, our rapidly changing climate, increasing popularity of beach recreation and growth of coastal development create growing and somewhat unpredictable threats. The project team will analyze variables that affect the rates of piping plover hatching success and adult mortality by expanding the scale and geographic range of data collection for nest exclosures (wire cages). The collection of hatching rates data will help with developing analytical tools for future management decisions.
properties.caption: Piping plover. Credit: Mike Morel, USFWS
refuges: Eastern Shore of Virginia National Wildlife Refuge
Edwin B. Forsythe National Wildlife Refuge
John H. Chafee National Wildlife Refuge
Elizabeth A. Morton National Wildlife Refuge

properties.name: Enhancement of Razorback Sucker Recruitment through Restoration of Sheppard Bottom, Ouray National Wildlife Refuge, Utah
properties.description: Recovery of endangered razorback sucker requires functional connections between rivers where the adult fish live and neighboring wetlands that act as nursery grounds for the young. Wetlands in the middle of Green River, including those at Ouray National Wildlife Refuge in Utah, provide crucial nursery habitat for the sucker, but recent habitat changes on the refuge, including construction of a levee, severed the connection between the Sheppard Bottom wetland and the Green River. The project team will help restore this connection by breaching the levee and facilitating water movement within the wetland. This will also benefit other endangered fish such as the bonytail and Colorado pikeminnow.
properties.caption: Adult Razerback sucker. Credit: Melanie Fischer, USFWS

properties.name: Lesser Prairie-Chicken Conservation and Recovery in Kansas
properties.description: Habitat fragmentation has been identified as a primary driver in the decline of the lesser prairie-chicken. The project team will reduce these threats by enhancing prairies to improve nesting and brood rearing habitat for the species. The project will address impacts from grassland invasion by woody plants, improper grazing systems, altered fire regimes and climate change. It builds on another Cooperative Recovery Initiative project that has demonstrated success by enhancing 7,000 acres of lesser prairie-chicken habitat on private lands and over 7,000 acres of habitat in Kansas on Quivira and Kirwin National Wildlife Refuges. Species that can additionally benefit are the Arkansas River shiner, whooping crane and least tern.
properties.caption: Lesser prairie-chicken. Credit: USDA

properties.name: Bull Trout Restoration: Restoring Cold, Clean, Complex and Connected Habitat in the Blackfoot River Watershed of Montana
properties.description: Habitat degradation and the effects of climate change are the biggest threats to threatened bull trout in the Blackfoot River watershed in Montana. Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks has determined that 90% of all tributaries to the Blackfoot River have extensive habitat degradation that is affecting bull trout populations. The project team will restore high quality habitat for the bull trout and other native salmonids within the Blackfoot Valley Conservation Area, a refuge conservation easement area, in the Blackfoot River watershed. The team will restore instream flows, restore water quality with best management practices for grazing livestock, remove fish passage barriers and install fish screens within in bull trout core areas. This project can also benefit native species, such as the grizzly bear.
properties.caption: Bull trout. Credit: Joel Sartore, National Geographic Stock with Wade Fredenberg, USFWS

properties.name: Grizzly Bear Aware: Conflict Resolution/Management and Habitat Restoration in the Centennial Valley and Southwest Montana
properties.description: Decades of recovery work have helped grizzly bear populations substantially rebound in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem. Human-related mortalities are the number one cause of death for Yellowstone grizzly bears. Recovery and linkage to unoccupied habitat westward in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem largely depend on how well humans accept bears, limit conflicts and limit human-caused mortality. The project team will implement conflict abatement measures, education and improve riparian corridors in sage-steppe landscape. It will reduce conflicts and human caused mortality and improve acceptance of grizzly bears around the Red Rock Lakes National Wildlife Refuge in Montana.
properties.caption: Grizzly bear in Yellowstone. Credit: Terry Tollefsbol, USFWS
refuges: Red Rock Lakes National Wildlife Refuge

properties.name: Development of a Correction Factor for Estimating Abundance of Sea Otters in the Threatened Southwestern Alaska Stock
properties.description: The southwest distinct population segment of northern sea otter in Alaska is a threatened species. The Eastern Aleutian management unit within the Alaska Maritime National Wildlife Refuge has been identified as a high priority for further recovery due to the lack of abundance and trend information. Aerial and boat-based surveys can provide only rough estimates of abundance due to imperfect detection of sea otters. The project team will conduct concurrent aerial surveys and boat-based surveys for two years in the Eastern Aleutians, which will allow the team to calculate a correction factor to estimate total abundance. Refuge staff will provide critical support from their research vessel, R/V Tiglax, which provides a unique research platform that is ideal for accessing some of the most remote locations in Alaska, including the study area.
properties.caption: Northern sea otter. Credit: jordantea CC BY-NC 2.0

properties.name: San Diego National Wildlife Refuge Quino Checkerspot Butterfly Augmentation Project, California
properties.description: The project team will contribute to the recovery of the endangered Quino checkerspot butterfly by increasing the number of stable populations and total number of individuals of this subspecies on the San Diego National Wildlife Refuge in California. This project involves captive propagation and population augmentation of the butterfly. Implementation will also help improve captive breeding protocols for this subspecies, which will be transferable to future augmentation efforts required at other locations for subspecies recovery. These strategic actions will provide momentum needed to achieve the partnership and community support required to achieve all recovery criteria throughout the subspecies’ range in the near future.
properties.caption: Quino checkerspot butterfly. Credit: Adam Braziel, CC BY-ND 2.0

properties.name: Restoration of Dune Habitat and Weed Abatement to Prevent the Imminent Extinction of Lange’s Metalmark Butterfly on Antioch Dunes National Wildlife Refuge
properties.description: Antioch Dunes National Wildlife Refuge in California is the only national wildlife refuge in the country established to protect endangered plants and insects – the Antioch Dunes evening primrose, Contra Costa wallflower and Lange’s metalmark butterfly. Loss of the dune habitat and infestation by invasive plants on remaining habitat is considered the cause of the Lange’s metalmark butterfly’s decline. Unprecedented dune restoration has begun and requires dune management, while continued weed abatement remains the most labor-intensive and costly endeavor towards recovery of the butterfly. Nearby San Pablo Bay National Wildlife Refuge’s existing nursery facilities will be used to propagate plants and harbor salvaged native plants for replanting. The project team will restore degraded dune habitat, replant dunes with native plants and remove invasive weeds that will improve foraging and breeding for the butterfly and benefit the two plant species.
properties.caption: Lange’s Metalmark butterfly. Credit: USFWS
